children.subject: I'm not sure, but it's not uncommon.  The faculty report many requests (at least one hundred or more from lower-division students mention it each term), and it's one of the most common reasons for advising appointments during mid-semester. I've heard it mentioned in the Undergraduate Study Committee every year since I've been here (2013), but this is the first year they formally proposed a policy to mitigate it.
Just curious, how prevalent is the policy of intentionally failing lower division courses?
GG LUL
If only

r i p CS hopes and dreams of incoming students l0l

If only we could expand enrollment in CS to match demand...
they don't count for calculating the gpa cutoff, but you don't have to retake them at berkeley

Actually, I'm pretty sure you have to take 61A and 70 at Berkeley. And if you take a data structures course elsewhere, you'll still have to take 47B. Granted, things might have changed since I last read the requirements.

Very few places elsewhere have transferable equivalents, but it's technically possible. For example, someone who took 6.001 at MIT (at least, the old Scheme version) would probably have been able to replace 61AS, since our course is based off of theirs; I don't know of any other institution that has a 61A-equivalent course.
Laney College offers 61A equivalent, AFAIK not a single CC has 70 equivalent.

Students did a great job answering the question, but wanted to reiterate that transfer students can still receive credit for equivalents, but those courses aren't used in the calculation (this has always been the standard).
How does this affect students who take courses equivalent to cs61a/b/70 at community colleges before entering berkeley? Would those courses still count for applying to the major?
https://www.facebook.com/groups/berkeleycs/permalink/1289789531115917/
Thanks for linking; it's a vibrant discussion!
There's a discussion on the CS Facebook page as well: https://www.facebook.com/groups/berkeleycs/permalink/1289789531115917/
done, thanks
It may be helpful to pin this

This does not change the GPA requirement for any student, simply integrates failed courses moving forward.

(No student has a 3.2 requirement)

Does this mean that students whose first semester at Berkeley started in Fall 2014 would have to follow this policy and meet the new 3.2 GPA requirement or would the 3.0 requirement for that class remain the same?

I certainly see your point, but we as a campus are just following the standard grade point rules.  I've never heard of a university offering additional points for "A+" grades, but I wouldn't be surprised if somewhere did so.  My other thought is that students who get an "A+" in *any* of the prerequisites, probably won't need additional points to get into the major.
AFAIK quite a number of schools offer 4.3 for a A+, including a few Ivys.

Unsurprisingly, Wikipedia has some discussion of this.

tl;dr: most places don't, but many places also do. My instinct is that private universities (e.g. Ivys) do more frequently, although I've never kept track.
TIL! Thanks gentlemen.
Stanford does; lots of others do.

Not sure if this is the place to ask this,

but just wondering if there is any reason for an A+ to be weighted as a 4.0 instead of, say, a 4.3?

The way I see it is if an A+ were weighted higher than an A, there would be more incentive to go the extra mile to try to get an A+.

UPDATE: the faculty have voted & approved of this policy change. For students currently enrolled in CS 61A, 61B, and 70, please plan accordingly and come see us if you have any questions. The add/drop deadline is Feb 17.
Upper division courses don't count towards the GPA threshold anyway...?

For this statement: "The following grades will be included in the GPA threshold calculation, even if the course is retaken for credit: D+, D, D-, F, P, and NP—even if they are not counted in the UC Berkeley transcript GP", does this apply for upper-division courses too, or just lower-division courses that are used to declare the major? Thanks.
no, data 8/cs88 do not replace CS 61A.
If I take 61A, then take Data 8 + CS88, if i do better in Data 8 and CS 88 can that score replace 61A?
@Emerald Templeton
@John DeNero  to confirm, but I'm pretty sure this is just for the major.
No change has been made to the minor at this point.
Thank you!
Does this also apply to the CS minor?

Hi, it's a university policy that you can't repeat courses you pass. From here: http://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades

You may repeat a course only if you received a grade of D+, D, D-, F, or NP.

If you earned a grade of D+, D, D-, or F, and have taken the course only once:

  • you must take the course for a letter grade
  • both grades will show on your transcript, but only your most recent grade will be calculated into your GPA

Note: If you have repeated more than 12 units of credit, this does not apply.

If you earned an NP, and have taken the course only once before:

  • repeat the course for either a letter grade, if allowed in the course

or

  • on a passed/not passed basis.

12-Unit Repetition Limit

  • If you repeat courses in which you received a D+, D, D-, or F, the units are counted only once and only the most recently earned grades and grade points are used for the first 12 units repeated.
  • If you repeat more than 12 units, your grade-point average is based on all grades assigned and total units attempted.
[Can't math]

Hi, I specifically have a question about that last example of the policy in practice. I'm intended cogsci and taking EE16A P/NP. I am however now interested in declaring CS instead. Can I pass the class and still repeat it?
Those were just examples. CS 47B will indeed be used - you GPA will be calculated with CS 61A, 47B, and 70.

• A in CS C8, A in CS 88, A in 47A, B+ in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.15. (CSc8, CS88, and 47A grades not utilized)

I'm currently taking 47B this semester; so will this grade not be factored into the GPA calculation? I took a CS 61B class that transfers at a community college. So only my grades for CS 61A and CS 70 count?

Thank you!
If you were admitted Fall 2015 or later, 61A, 61B and 70, just like everyone else.
What is calculated as my declaration GPA if I take 61A, 61B, 70, C8, 88, and 47A?

Hi there,

The CS Advisors will respond directly to your email. 

Best,

Nicole

Had no idea about this policy until just this morning. I NP-ed 61a spring 2017 because I was pledging a business fraternity and was afraid I wasn't going to be able to meet GPA cap by end of fall 2017 (had NO IDEA pledging was going to be so time/energy/morale-consuming until halfway through which was way too late). This was a lot of bad luck and a little bit of irresponsibility on my part for not finding out about this policy sooner, because it wasn't on the website.

Because an NP grade is 0.0, I've been retaking 61a over the summer only to find out I would've had to make a 5.2 GPA in this class in order to make 3.3 GPA cap. I'm extremely worried and I really, really want to major CS. This was all just a huge misunderstanding because I didn't see this new policy posted on the CS major website. 

I was wondering what I could possibly do to declare CS? I'd be extremely grateful to learn of ANY possibility...
ur right! This was copy & paste from the proposal. Thanks for catching it! I've fixed it.
This question seems unrelated to repeat rules. Please email  <cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu> and include your SID #
If I double major in math/cs and want to use Math 55 to substitute cs70, will my Math 55 grade be counted for GPA to declare? Or only grades in cs61a and cs61b are needed?

I believe so. Math 54 isn't required to declare, but necessary for a couple upper division classes.

As long as your 61A grade was before Spring 2017 (when all attempts for CS61A/B/70 started to count), then you should be fine. The University will allow any failure grade to be overridden (but will still appear on your transcript), but for CS Major declaration, all grades in every course attempt for A/B/70 count as of Spring 2017.

Can I Rebound?
Hello! I had a medical issue during my Freshman year, so I got an F in 61A and a D in Math 54. If I retake both and get perfect grades can I declare?

You can't retake a class you didn't fail.

(In the old enrollment system, at least, you were able to still reenroll, but no one will recognize the second taking of the course / it won't count towards anything at all. So it would be pointless.)

The proposal does not apply to courses that the student received a “D+ or below” in during the Fall 2016 or prior semester; those can be retaken and only the retake grade will be utilized for the GPA calculation. In essence, the proposal applies to courses failed (including grades of D-, D, and D+) in Spring 2017 or thereafter. 

I intentionally failed the class in Fall 2016 because of my health issue and retook the class this semester. But, it seems that my old grade and new grade are all utilized for the GPA calculation (I checked the GPA in Calcentral.)

Is it a temporary error or am I misunderstanding the policy?

Thank you in advance and hope you have wonderful holidays! :)

Nothing about this changes how Berkeley calculates your GPA, or how CalCentral would display your GPA (which should be that only your new grade is used, unless you've already failed this class before / have retaken too many courses).

That is, you wouldn't see this policy change reflected in any listed GPA.

This only affects how your GPA is calculated for your CS declaration.
Are we allowed to retake classes we didn't fail (got say like a B in Fall 2016 CS61A) and use the new grade to help us declare?

This is very unfair to transfers, especially those who came here registering as CS majors. We have to take 13 units every semester while all other non-technical classes have been done in CC, which mean they can be all 13 technical units. Also, we are not the ones to make the majors impacted this much, we came here with the mindset to major in CS, not to take the classes to see how they are like. Declaring as a CS major at this school was already hard, not it's even tougher. I really hope that there's a separate policy for those who got admitted here (transfers) as CS intended majors
Why would retaking 61A or B be relevant to a deficient grade in 70?
No, sorry. Your 61A grade only contributes 4 units to the weighted total, even if it involves two or more averaged grades.
if someone got an A- in 61A, an A in 61B and a C in 70, could they retake either 61A or 61B, achieve an A- or higher and declare?
no

<md>What if I use late drop to drop cs61b when I realize I might not be able to get a decent grade. Then I take it again in the future semester. Will the previous grade (nonexistent grade) be counted as the part of final average?</md>
If I took CS 70 as P/NP and received a NP for it, and then later retake it for CS minor application, will the grade of NP will be calculated into the GPA requirement for the application or not?

history.content:
In light of the high demand for EECS courses and the CS major, the faculty have revised our major admissions policy to discourage CS-intended students from intentionally failing lower-division courses. This practice delays student progress, increases enrollment in lower-division courses, and can lead students to make decisions that they later regret. Lower-division courses required for the major should be taken for a letter grade, and students who intend to major in CS should endeavor to pass. The policy change encourages CS-intended students to do so.

 

This change is within the purview of the Director of CS Undergraduate Matters, and the Vice Chair of CS Undergraduate matters, it has already been voted on and approved by the EECS Undergraduate Study Committee and is effective Spring 2017

The policy is as follows. A student's GPA will be computed for the purpose of admission to the L&S CS major as follows:

 

  • Only CS 61A, CS 61B, and CS 70 grades for courses taken at UC Berkeley will be counted. If a student retakes any of these courses, both the original and retaken grade will be utilized in the GPA calculation for entry to the L&S CS major. 
  • This is true even if the course is retaken for credit: D+, D, D-, F, and NP—even if they are not counted in the UC Berkeley transcript GPA.
    • Exception: These grades received in Fall 2016 or earlier will be excluded if the course is retaken for a letter grade in any future semester.
  • The UC Berkeley 4-point grading scale will be used for letter grades. [1]
  • All courses taken towards the major must be taken for a letter grade. If you think you might be interested in the CS major, do not take any of these courses P/NP. If a student receives a NP in a pre-req, it will be factored as an F (0.0 grade points) when their CS major application is reviewed. 

 

It is still possible for non-majors to take lower-division courses P/NP, which is a sensible grading option for students who are taking courses solely for interest. It is also still possible to retake a course for credit according to campus policies, and the official campus GPA is not affected by this proposal. 

 

[1] https://orapps.berkeley.edu/Registrar/grades_gpa.html

 

Examples of the policy in practice:

  • A+ in CS 61A, B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.33.
  • NP in CS 61A, A in CS 61A (repeated), B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 2.50.
  • A in CS C8, A in CS 88, A in 47A, B+ in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.15. (CSc8, CS88, and 47A grades not utilized)

TL;DR If retaking a CS major pre-req, both the original and retaken grade will be utilized in the GPA calculation for entry to the L&S CS major. 

#pin

#pin
history.subject: Retake rules for the L&S CS major GPA threshold

history.content:
UPDATE: The EECS faculty have already voted and approved of this change. Effective Sp 17.

In light of the high demand for EECS courses and the CS major, the faculty are considering a proposal that revises our major admissions policy to discourage CS-intended students from intentionally failing lower-division courses. This practice delays student progress, increases enrollment in lower-division courses, and can lead students to make decisions that they later regret. Lower-division courses required for the major should be taken for a letter grade, and students who intend to major in CS should endeavor to pass. The proposed policy change encourages CS-intended students to do so.

 

The new proposal has already been voted on and approved by the EECS Undergraduate Study Committee, and the vote for final approval by all faculty will take place on January 30, 2017.  We expect final approval to go through, so please plan as if the policy is effective immediately.   

The policy is as follows:

 

A student's GPA will be computed for the purpose of admission to the L&S CS major as follows:

 

  • Only CS 61A, CS 61B, and CS 70 grades for courses taken at UC Berkeley will be counted.
  • The following grades will be included in the GPA threshold calculation, even if the course is retaken for credit: D+, D, D-, F, and NP—even if they are not counted in the UC Berkeley transcript GPA.
    • Exception: These grades received in Fall 2016 or earlier will be excluded if the course is retaken for a letter grade in any future semester.
  • The UC Berkeley 4-point grading scale will be used for letter grades. [1]
  • All courses taken towards the major, must be taken for a letter grade. If you think you might be interested in the CS major, do not take any of these courses P/NP.

 

It is still possible for non-majors to take lower-division courses P/NP, which is a sensible grading option for students who are taking courses solely for interest. It is also still possible to retake a course for credit according to campus policies, and the official campus GPA is not affected by this proposal. 

 

[1] https://orapps.berkeley.edu/Registrar/grades_gpa.html

 

Examples of the policy in practice:

  • A+ in CS 61A, B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.33.
  • NP in CS 61A, A in CS 61A (repeated), B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 2.50.
  • A in CS C8, A in CS 88, A in 47A, B+ in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.15. (CSc8, CS88, and 47A grades not utilized)
  • P in CS 61A, A- in 61B, A- in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.03

 

TL;DR Faculty are considering a proposal to change course retake rules so that both the original and retaken prereq grade will be utilized in the GPA calculation for entry to the L&S CS major.  The proposal does not apply to courses that the student received a “D+ or below” in during the Fall 2016 or prior semester; those can be retaken and only the retake grade will be utilized for the GPA calculation. In essence, the proposal applies to courses failed (including grades of D-, D, and D+) in Spring 2017 or thereafter. 

 

#pin
history.subject: Retake rules for the L&S CS major GPA threshold

history.content:
UPDATE: The EECS faculty have already voted and approved of this change. Effective Sp 17.

In light of the high demand for EECS courses and the CS major, the faculty are considering a proposal that revises our major admissions policy to discourage CS-intended students from intentionally failing lower-division courses. This practice delays student progress, increases enrollment in lower-division courses, and can lead students to make decisions that they later regret. Lower-division courses required for the major should be taken for a letter grade, and students who intend to major in CS should endeavor to pass. The proposed policy change encourages CS-intended students to do so.

 

The new proposal has already been voted on and approved by the EECS Undergraduate Study Committee, and the vote for final approval by all faculty will take place on January 30, 2017.  We expect final approval to go through, so please plan as if the policy is effective immediately.   

The policy is as follows:

 

A student's GPA will be computed for the purpose of admission to the L&S CS major as follows:

 

  • Only CS 61A, CS 61B, and CS 70 grades for courses taken at UC Berkeley will be counted.
  • The following grades will be included in the GPA threshold calculation, even if the course is retaken for credit: D+, D, D-, F, and NP—even if they are not counted in the UC Berkeley transcript GPA.
    • Exception: These grades received in Fall 2016 or earlier will be excluded if the course is retaken for a letter grade in any future semester.
  • The UC Berkeley 4-point grading scale will be used for letter grades. [1]
  • A grade of P will be scored as a C- (1.7), and a grade of NP will be scored as an F (0.0).

 

It is still possible for non-majors to take lower-division courses P/NP, which is a sensible grading option for students who are taking courses solely for interest. It is also still possible to retake a course for credit according to campus policies, and the official campus GPA is not affected by this proposal. 

 

[1] https://orapps.berkeley.edu/Registrar/grades_gpa.html

 

Examples of the policy in practice:

  • A+ in CS 61A, B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.33.
  • NP in CS 61A, A in CS 61A (repeated), B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 2.50.
  • A in CS C8, A in CS 88, A in 47A, B+ in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.15. (CSc8, CS88, and 47A grades not utilized)
  • P in CS 61A, A- in 61B, A- in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.03

 

TL;DR Faculty are considering a proposal to change course retake rules so that both the original and retaken prereq grade will be utilized in the GPA calculation for entry to the L&S CS major.  The proposal does not apply to courses that the student received a “D+ or below” in during the Fall 2016 or prior semester; those can be retaken and only the retake grade will be utilized for the GPA calculation. In essence, the proposal applies to courses failed (including grades of D-, D, and D+) in Spring 2017 or thereafter.

  • A in CS C8, A in CS 88, A in 47A, B+ in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.15. (CSc8, CS88, and 47A grades not utilized)
  • P in CS 61A, A- in 61B, A- in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.03

 

TL;DR Faculty are considering a proposal to change course retake rules so that both the original and retaken prereq grade will be utilized in the GPA calculation for entry to the L&S CS major.  The proposal does not apply to courses that the student received a “D+ or below” in during the Fall 2016 or prior semester; those can be retaken and only the retake grade will be utilized for the GPA calculation. In essence, the proposal applies to courses failed (including grades of D-, D, and D+) in Spring 2017 or thereafter. 

 

#pin
history.subject: Retake rules for the L&S CS major GPA threshold (changed SP 17)

history.content:
UPDATE: The EECS faculty have already voted and approved of this change. Effective Sp 17.

In light of the high demand for EECS courses and the CS major, the faculty are considering a proposal that revises our major admissions policy to discourage CS-intended students from intentionally failing lower-division courses. This practice delays student progress, increases enrollment in lower-division courses, and can lead students to make decisions that they later regret. Lower-division courses required for the major should be taken for a letter grade, and students who intend to major in CS should endeavor to pass. The proposed policy change encourages CS-intended students to do so.

 

The new proposal has already been voted on and approved by the EECS Undergraduate Study Committee, and the vote for final approval by all faculty will take place on January 30, 2017.  We expect final approval to go through, so please plan as if the policy is effective immediately.   

The policy is as follows:

 

A student's GPA will be computed for the purpose of admission to the L&S CS major as follows:

 

  • Only CS 61A, CS 61B, and CS 70 grades for courses taken at UC Berkeley will be counted.
  • The following grades will be included in the GPA threshold calculation, even if the course is retaken for credit: D+, D, D-, F, P, and NP—even if they are not counted in the UC Berkeley transcript GPA.
    • Exception: These grades received in Fall 2016 or earlier will be excluded if the course is retaken for a letter grade in any future semester.
  • The UC Berkeley 4-point grading scale will be used for letter grades. [1]
  • A grade of P will be scored as a C- (1.7), and a grade of NP will be scored as an F (0.0).

 

It is still possible for non-majors to take lower-division courses P/NP, which is a sensible grading option for students who are taking courses solely for interest. It is also still possible to retake a course for credit according to campus policies, and the official campus GPA is not affected by this proposal. 

 

[1] https://orapps.berkeley.edu/Registrar/grades_gpa.html

 

Examples of the policy in practice:

  • A+ in CS 61A, B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.33.
  • NP in CS 61A, A in CS 61A (repeated), B in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 2.50.
  • A in CS C8, A in CS 88, A in 47A, B+ in CS 61B, B in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.15. (CSc8, CS88, and 47A grades not utilized)
  • P in CS 61A, A- in 61B, A- in CS 70 -> GPA is 3.23

 

TL;DR Faculty are considering a proposal to change course retake rules so that both the original and retaken prereq grade will be utilized in the GPA calculation for entry to the L&S CS major.  The proposal does not apply to courses that the student received a “D+ or below” in during the Fall 2016 or prior semester; those can be retaken and only the retake grade will be utilized for the GPA calculation. In essence, the proposal applies to courses failed (including grades of D-, D, and D+) in Spring 2017 or thereafter.
